pymam package¶

Submodules¶

pymam.audio module¶

Audio module

pymam.audio.sound(x, fs=44100, blocking=True)[source]¶

Play sound from x array at given sampling rate

pymam.audio.soundsc(x, fs=44100)[source]¶

Play normalized sound from x array at given sampling rate

pymam.audio.wavread24(file)[source]¶

Read a WAV file.

file : string or file object
Either the name of a file or an open file pointer.
rate : float
The sampling frequency (i.e. frame rate)
sampwidth : float
The sample width, in bytes. E.g. for a 24 bit WAV file, sampwidth is 3.
data : numpy array
The array containing the data. The shape of the array is (num_samples, num_channels). num_channels is the number of audio channels (1 for mono, 2 for stereo).

This function uses the wave module of the Python standard libary to read the WAV file, so it has the same limitations as that library. In particular, the function does not read compressed WAV files.

pymam.audio.wavwrite24(filename, rate, data)[source]¶

Create a 24 bit wav file.

filename : string
Name of the file to create.
rate : float
The sampling frequency (i.e. frame rate) of the data.
data : array-like collection of integer or floating point values
data must be “array-like”, either 1- or 2-dimensional. If it is 2-d, the rows are the frames (i.e. samples) and the columns are the channels.

The data is assumed to be signed, and the values are assumed to be within the range of a 24 bit integer. Floating point values are converted to integers. The data is not rescaled or normalized before writing it to the file.

Create a 3 second 440 Hz sine wave.

>>> rate = 22050  # samples per second
>>> T = 3         # sample duration (seconds)
>>> f = 440.0     # sound frequency (Hz)
>>> t = np.linspace(0, T, T*rate, endpoint=False)
>>> x = (2**23 - 1) * np.sin(2 * np.pi * f * t)
>>> writewav24("sine24.wav", rate, x)
pymam.audio.wavread(file_name)[source]¶
pymam.audio.wavwrite(file_name, x, fs=44100)[source]¶

pymam.plot.plot_cov_ellipse(cov, pos, volume=0.5, ax=None, fc='none', ec=[0, 0, 0], a=1, lw=2)[source]¶

Plots an ellipse enclosing volume based on the specified covariance matrix (cov) and location (pos). Additional keyword arguments are passed on to the ellipse patch artist.

cov : The 2x2 covariance matrix to base the ellipse on pos : The location of the center of the ellipse. Expects a 2-element

sequence of [x0, y0].

volume : The volume inside the ellipse; defaults to 0.5 ax : The axis that the ellipse will be plotted on. Defaults to the

current axis.

pymam.signal.tukeywin(window_length, alpha=0.5)[source]¶

The Tukey window, also known as the tapered cosine window, can be regarded as a cosine lobe of width lpha * N / 2 that is convolved with a rectangle window of width (1 - lpha / 2). At lpha = 1 it becomes rectangular, and at lpha = 0 it becomes a Hann window.

We use the same reference as MATLAB to provide the same results in case users compare a MATLAB output to this function output

http://www.mathworks.com/access/helpdesk/help/toolbox/signal/tukeywin.html
pymam.signal.stft(x, fs, winsize, win=<function hamming at 0x2b2bd22442a8>, olap=None)[source]¶
pymam.signal.butter_filter(data, cutoff, fs, btype='low', order=5, ab=False)[source]¶
pymam.signal.autocorrelation(x, maxlag=0, norm='true')[source]¶

Compute autocorrelation using FFT The idea comes from http://dsp.stackexchange.com/a/1923/4363 (Hilmar)

pymam.tukeywin(window_length, alpha=0.5)¶

The Tukey window, also known as the tapered cosine window, can be regarded as a cosine lobe of width lpha * N / 2 that is convolved with a rectangle window of width (1 - lpha / 2). At lpha = 1 it becomes rectangular, and at lpha = 0 it becomes a Hann window.

We use the same reference as MATLAB to provide the same results in case users compare a MATLAB output to this function output

http://www.mathworks.com/access/helpdesk/help/toolbox/signal/tukeywin.html

Plots an ellipse enclosing volume based on the specified covariance matrix (cov) and location (pos). Additional keyword arguments are passed on to the ellipse patch artist.

current axis.

pymam.wavread24(file)¶

Read a WAV file.

file : string or file object
Either the name of a file or an open file pointer.
rate : float
The sampling frequency (i.e. frame rate)
sampwidth : float
The sample width, in bytes. E.g. for a 24 bit WAV file, sampwidth is 3.
data : numpy array
The array containing the data. The shape of the array is (num_samples, num_channels). num_channels is the number of audio channels (1 for mono, 2 for stereo).

This function uses the wave module of the Python standard libary to read the WAV file, so it has the same limitations as that library. In particular, the function does not read compressed WAV files.

pymam.wavwrite24(filename, rate, data)¶

Create a 24 bit wav file.

filename : string
Name of the file to create.
rate : float
The sampling frequency (i.e. frame rate) of the data.
data : array-like collection of integer or floating point values
data must be “array-like”, either 1- or 2-dimensional. If it is 2-d, the rows are the frames (i.e. samples) and the columns are the channels.

The data is assumed to be signed, and the values are assumed to be within the range of a 24 bit integer. Floating point values are converted to integers. The data is not rescaled or normalized before writing it to the file.

Create a 3 second 440 Hz sine wave.

>>> rate = 22050  # samples per second
>>> T = 3         # sample duration (seconds)
>>> f = 440.0     # sound frequency (Hz)
>>> t = np.linspace(0, T, T*rate, endpoint=False)
>>> x = (2**23 - 1) * np.sin(2 * np.pi * f * t)
>>> writewav24("sine24.wav", rate, x)
